WILLIAM REYNOLDS
. I accompanied Isaacs, on the 27th of May, to Cobb's yard; when a signal was given, I ran to the house, and seized the prisoner by the left hand - his sister ran to the privy; I went and seized hold of her hand, but found nothing.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. Sheriman was employed by me to buy these things of the prisoner; I gave him four marked shillings, one half crown, and a sixpence not marked; I had searched him. but found nothing else about him - I went to the public-house a little after one o'clock; he was then in custody; I searched the privy next day - I let Kirby down with a rope, and he found these two bags, one within the other; the inner one contains seven half sovereigns, one hundred and fifteen shillings, and eighty half crowns; Sheriman produced twenty bad shillings to me directly I took hold of the prisoner, and said, in the prisoner's presence, that he had them from him - I saw Lloyd take these four marked shillings from the prisoner's pocket - Sheriman had described the bag to me.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Were you not informed that the prisoner's sister had put her hand down the privy? A. Yes, at the office - I did not know it till then; the privy is surrounded by a brick wall.

WILLIAM KIRBY
. I was with Limbrick on the 27th; I went next day and got this bag from the privy, about ten o'clock.
Cross-examined. Q. Was the door of the house locked? A. Yes; the woman at the next house had the key.

ANDREW LLOYD
. I produce the four marked shillings which I got from the prisoner's left hand trousers pocket.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. These are what I marked.

JOHN FIELD
. I am an inspector of coin. These twenty shillings are all counterfeit; they are in separate papers, being so slightly covered with silver - eighteen are from one die, and two from another; there are some from both dies in the bag - they are all bad half crowns and half sovereigns.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Are they fit for circulation? A. They are not what is called"rubbed down;" they now represent money just come from the Mint; the persons who pass them generally rub them down - thousands have been passed in this state.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
There was another indictment against the prisoner.
Transported for Seven Years .

1290.
LEAH ABRAHAMS
was indicted for a
like offence .

ROBERT SHERIMAN
. On the 12th of May , I met John Limbrick at the Crown tavern, at a quarter to three o'clock; Isaacs was there - I was searched, and received four shillings; I went to Cobb's-yard, Petticoat-lane
, to Abraham's house; knocked at the door - the prisoner opened it; I asked her if Yankee was at home, meaning her brother; she said, No, could not she do; I said,"Yes, I want a score of bobs;" she went to the privy, brought out a bag - gave me out a score; I gave her the four shillings which I had received from Limbrick, and took the bobs to his house that evening; I think there were twelve or fourteen score more in the bag - I think it was the same bag as was produced in the last case.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Was anybody else present? A. No. Isaacs followed me there, and saw me come out - the things in the bag were in paper; they were parcels of the same size as mine.

JAMES ISAACS
. I followed Sheriman to the prisoner's house, saw him go in, and waited five or six minutes till he came out; on the 27th I saw the prisoner taken.
Cross-examined. Q. How long were you with Sheriman? A. From three to five o'clock, when he saw Limbrick - he could not have got the coin from anybody else.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. On the 12th of May I searched Sheriman, and gave him four marked shillings; he gave me a score of bad shillings - the same day I searched both him and Isaacs, and found nothing on them but this counterfeit money.
ROBERT SHERIMAN. I was at the house again on the 27th; I saw the prisoner snatch up something, and go to the privy.
JURY. Q. Where did your wife get the money she is in custody about? A. I got it for her from Abrahams; she was tried on the 10th of March.

WILLIAM KIRBY
. I went on the 27th, and found these bags in the privy.
MR. REYNOLDS. On the 27th of May I was at the house, and saw the prisoner run to the privy, and seized her with her hand down the privy.

JOHN FIELD
. These shillings are all counterfeit, and all of one die - they are of the same die as some in the bag.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

1291.
GEORGE SMITH
,
JOHN ROBINS
, and
HENRY ARMSTRONG
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of May , 1 scarf, value 30s. , the goods of
Thomas Corderoy
.

ELIZABETH CORDEROY
. I am the wife of Thomas Corderoy, a dyer , of Battle-bridge
. On the 28th of May, about six o'clock, I locked the shop-door, and went down stairs; I came up in a few minutes, and found Smith and Robins in the shop, at the counter - I had left the key outside the door, which opens into the passage; one of them asked me what I would dye a pair of trousers for; I told them, and they left; I then missed a scarf off the counter - I had seen it safe when I went away; I went to the door, pursued them, and brought them back.

JOSEPH CADBY
. I am an officer. I was fetched, and took Robins and Smith; I tied them together; Smith cried, and said he had given the scarf to a boy named Turner; he took me to Somers'-town to Turner, who said he had given it to Armstrong - we went to him, and he gave it up.
SMITH'S Defence. Turner unlocked the door - not me.
The prisoners received a good character.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 11.

ROBINS -
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Whipped and Discharged .

ARMSTRONG -
NOT GUILTY .

1292.
SIMEON ODWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of May , 1 ass, price 20s. , the property of
William Oxley
.
The prosecutor did not appear NOT GUILTY .

1293.
MATTHIAS ISAAC LEWIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of May , 24 penny-pieces , the monies of
William Wilson
.

WILLIAM WILSON. I keep a rag-shop in Back-lane, St. George's in the East
. On the 22d of May I saw the prisoner behind my counter - he must have crept in upon his hands and knees; he had taken the till out, and placed it on a bag on the floor; I went to him - he said a person had thrown in his cap, and he came to fetch it; I had left the till safe five minutes before - it contained copper.

CHARLES CHAPMAN
. I am an officer, and took him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. A boy threw my cap in; I saw the till on the floor.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .

1294.
HENRY INWOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 12 pairs of stockings, value 8s. , the goods of
Samuel Everingham
.

JAMES QUIN
. On the 29th of May I was in Oxford-street
, and saw the prisoner and another boy at Mr. Everingham's shop, standing near a roll of flannel; I saw the prisoner take these stockings off a roll of flannel, roll them in his apron, and run down Berwick-street; I ran in, and gave information; two young men ran out, but could not find him; I afterwards saw the same two lads in Regent-street - the prisoner had the stockings in his apron; I took hold of him - the other got away; the prisoner dropped the stockings, and said, "I did not take them."

JOHN EVERINGHAM
. I am servant to Mr. Samuel Everingham. I went out, but could see no boys - these stockings are my master's property.
GUILTY . Aged 9.
Whipped and Discharged .

1295.
CHARLES TOSANTE BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of February , 26 yards of linen, value 3l.; 11 yards of ribbon, value 8s.; 10 yards of silk, value 45s., and 44 buttons, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas Edwards
, his master .
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS EDWARDS. I am a linen-draper , and live in High-street, Mary-le-bone
; the prisoner was in my employ about five months, and left about the 20th of February - I had no suspicion of him; I ordered him to take stock of the Irish linens in November - there was a piece among them, which I have since seen - it is marked "No. 60, M. G. W." in my own writing; I received information in May last, and went to Susannah Bowen, who shewed me part of that piece of linen; I did not know of any of it being sold; she also shewed me some grosde de Naples, some ribbon, and pearl buttons; the prisoner had no authority to dispose of my goods on his own account, nor on commission, neither for me nor anybody else - I never knew of his selling goods to Bowen; there is an account in my stock-book of some of the linen being sold.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. He left you on the 20th? A. Yes; he went out on pleasure I understood - he returned on the Monday, and said his absence was caused by illness; I said I should not take him again, and he went away; I saw him again a few days after at his lodgings, No. 27, London-terrace, Hackney-road; I did not say I was sorry I could not take him again - I have a person named Balding in my employ - he is here; I never knew of my servants selling goods to each other - he proposed to take the stock in November.

Mr. CLARKSON. Q. Did you ever authorize them to sell to each other? A. I authorized Balding to sell the prisoner twenty-four yards of gros de Naples, but nothing else - it has not been paid for; here is the stock-book - this piece is entered as cut, and not to be put with whole pieces.

COURT. Q. Was the stock taken by him or you? A. By him; it was only of the Irish linen; I saw this Irish entered in the book, and might see the piece - it was marked when it came in, which was not twelve months ago; I had no other of that mark; the book is in the prisoner's handwriting - he states it to be on hand in November.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Are you quite sure you never authorized him to dispose of this linen? A. Yes.

SUSANNAH BOWEN
. I am the wife of
Thomas Bowen
, and live at No. 27, London-terrace. I am a dress-maker. About this time last year I made up some millinery for the prisoner, and in February last he came with some - I worked for him till then; he said he lived with Mr. Edwards, and that in July Mr. Edwards was going to take him into partnership; that he had a large sum coming to him, and that Mr. Edwards had a warehouse in Cheapside, and allowed him part of it, and two days in a week to sell by commission: he brought me patterns of different articles to purchase; I gave him an order on the 10th of February for a whole piece of Irish, which I received; I cut part of it up, and the other is in possession of the officer - it was marked "No. 60, M. G. W." I also ordered ten yards of gros de Naples; he brought some gauze ribbons, and pearl buttons, which I had not ordered.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you always given the same account of this transaction? A. Yes; I told the Magistrate that he said he was allowed to sell on commission; here is"No. 6" on the Irish - the letters are on the paper it was in.

HENRY STOWEL
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner in Cold Arbour-street, Hackney, on the 15th of May; he denied the charge; I said, "You recollect the linen and things you sold Mrs. Bowen?" he said, "I did; they were Mr. Edward's once, but I bought them of him."
MR. EDWARDS. I believe this to be my linen: this mark on it is my writing - the other goods are mine: I never authorized him to sell any of them - here is a remnant which matches the silk.

Prisoner's Defence. This Irish was not his; I was in the habit of purchasing goods from two hawkers for four or five years, and serving my friends in the country - I had the linen from one of the hawkers: but I cannot ascertain in what part of the country he is now in.

THOMAS BALDING
. I am servant to Mr. Edwards. I sold the prisoner a piece of silk of Mr. Edwards'; it was this piece of gros de Naples; I cut it from this piece - he had not paid for it; I was told to cut it off, and I did.
COURT. Q. When was this? A. I do not recollect the month; I cut him twenty-four yards, and entered it in a book - master told me to let him have it; I am his apprentice.
MRS. BOWEN. I bought twenty-four yards of black-silk of him, besides this ten yards; I made up all the twenty-four yards - this is not part of it.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1296.
WILLIAM MURTAGH
and
ROBERT HAYWARD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 36 harness ornaments, value 30s.; 48 harness buckles, value 1l.; 18 swivels. value 15s., and 1 snaffle, value 3s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Kearley
and
Joseph Leonard Kearley
.

THOMAS ORPWOOD
. I am servant to Thomas Kearley and Joseph Leonard Kearley, of Long-acre
, army contractors
; the prisoners were their apprentice
s. On Friday, about eleven o'clock, Martin came and said, he had found three parcels in the water-closet; I told him to put them back and watch the place - about one o'clock I went up stairs; the prisoners came from the privy and went up stairs for their coats, to go to dinner - I went out; they came out - I told them to walk back; I found in Murtagh's pocket, this bundle of swivels, and several other articles; and on Hayward, this bundle of ornaments, and in his hat these other articles.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long had they been in your service? A. Some time; their friends are respectable - I asked why they took them; they said, they had a little money to make up.

JOSEPH MARTIN
. I am the gate-keeper. I found these two parcels in the water-closet, with another, which we have not found.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoners received a good character.

MURTAGH -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

HAYWARD -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Strongly recommended to mercy -
Confined 3 Months .

1297.
MARGARET HURLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of May , 1 coat, value 15s. , the goods of
Charles Paul
.

CHARLES PAUL. I lodge in King's Head-buildings, Westminster
; the prisoner lodged on the same floor - I lost this coat from my box.

HANNAH SYMMONS
. I keep the house; Paul is my brother - I saw him put his coat in the box; the prisoner lodged there for two months - I have lent her things of mine to pawn when she was in distress.

EDWARD DAVIS
. I am shopman to Mr. Rochford, a pawnbroker, of Jermyn-street; the prisoner pawned this coat on the 26th of May. Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went into his room; he gave me a sovereign to go and redeem some things - I would not give him his change until Monday, as he was in liquor; I did not see his coat.
CHARLES PAUL. I never authorised her to pawn anything.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Confined Three Months .

1298.
MARY HERBERT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of May , 1 veil, value 20s., the goods of
Thomas Franklin
, her master .

ELIZABETH ANN FRANKLIN
. I am the wife of Thomas Franklin, of Oxford-street
: the prisoner was about a month in our service - she left on the 23d of May, and on the Sunday after, I missed this veil from my bed-room drawers - I never allowed her to take it; it is lace, and cost five guineas.

HENRY GODDARD
. I am an officer, and searched the prisoner's lodgings, No. 2. New-road, near Sloane-street; I told her what I came for; she said, the veil was in her box - I found it there.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1299.
WILLIAM GLEESON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of May , 1 lantern, value 2s.; 4 keys, value 1s., and a pair of gloves, value 4d. , the goods of
Patrick MacNamara
.

PATRICK MACNAMARA. I am a private watchman of Euston-square
. On the 25th of May at night I left my lantern in my box, while I went to look about the premises; I also left my gloves and keys there - when I returned they were all gone; I saw the prisoner getting over the pailings with the lantern in his hand - I asked what he took them for; he said, it was a lark, and I said, I would take him to the watch-house: he ran away - Campbell stopped him; the keys were found about four yards from my box - I had seen the prisoner before, but he was no friend of mine.

JOHN CAMPBELL
. I am a watchman. I was on duty in Gower-street - I heard the cry of Stop thief! and took the prisoner; the gloves were found on him.
Prisoner's Defence. I took the lantern and called Mike, thinking a friend of mine was there, who used to watch there, the gloves fell down; I thought they were my own, and took them up.
PROSECUTOR. The prisoner was once a watchman; I came in his place; he was only a few yards from my box.
NOT GUILTY .

1300.
MARIA WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of April , 1 sovereign; 1 half-crown, and 3 shillings, the monies of
John Stevens
, from his person .
The Prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1301.
WILLIAM DAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of May , 9lbs. of lead, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Maria Murray
, widow , and fixed to a building .

SECOND COUNT, stating it to be the property of
John Bradley Shuttleworth
.

RICHARD WILLIAM COOKE
. I am a constable of Kingston-on-Thames. On the 10th of May. I had information, and caused the prisoner to be apprehended in Kingston; he was routed out of a public-house with another man, who ran away - I asked where he had sold the lead; he said, he had sold it at Smith's, a dealer in marine stores - I got some lead from Smith; I afterwards fitted the lead to the green-house of Mrs. Murray, at Hampton-court - the prisoner said, he had it from one Rainscome to sell for him that he gave him the money.

FRANCIS SMITH
. I am a dealer in marine-stores, at Kingston. On the 10th of May, at half-past eight o'clock in the morning, I bought 29lbs. of lead of the prisoner, and gave it up to the officer; I asked where he got it - he said he went out collecting materials; I paid him 1 1/2d. a lb. - I made no farther enquiry.

RICHARD LONG
. I am gardener to Mr. John Bradley Shuttleworth. Maria Murray lives on the premises - I missed this lead from the green-house in the morning of the 10th; I have seen it compared, and believe it to be the same.
NOT GUILTY .

1302.
JOHN COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of April , 14 pairs of shoes, value 45s. , the goods of
Francis Homan
.

FRANCIS HOMAN. I am a shoe-manufacturer , and live in Shoreditch
: the prisoner was my porter and groom - I did not miss this property.

ISAAC NONMUS
. I am traveller to Mr. Homan. I found five duplicates in the stable, on two different occasions, among the horses' litter: nobody but the prisoner worked there - I gave the duplicates to the officer.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is there a table-beer cellar by the side of the stable? A. Yes; other persons have access to it; the stable-door is open all day.

JOSEPH HAMMOND
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner; I found a pair of shoes on his wife's feet - the private mark is erased; Mr. Homan claimed them.

RICHARD STEVEN KILLEN
. On the 22d of April, I went to the stable to clean the horses, and found some duplicates.

JAMES RIBBENS
. I am warehouseman to Mr. Homan; he has eight or nine men; I found one duplicate in the stable; I do not know whether the prisoner's wife used to come there.

ROBERT COX
. I am a pawnbroker of Great Charlotte-street, Blackfriar's-road - I have two pairs of womens' shoes, pawned on the 19th of March, in the name of Ann Collens; I do not know by whom.

CHARLES HOUGHTON
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 31st of March, two pairs of shoes were pawned in the name of Johnson; I cannot say who by.

JOHN BENNETT
. I have a pair of shoes pawned on the 3d of April, in the name of Ann Johnson; I do not know by whom.

JOHN HOLSWORTH
. I am a pawnbroker, and have two pairs of shoes pawned in the name of Johnson; I do not know who by.

LAWRENCE NOTLEY
. I am a pawnbroker, and have two pairs of shoes pawned on the 21st of April, in the name of Ann Johnson: I do not know by whom.

JOSEPH WOOLSTENHOLME
. I have a pair of shoes pawned in the name of Smith; I cannot say by whom.(Property produced and sworn to.)
MR. HOMAN. The prisoner's wife never came to my house, until after he was apprehended.
NOT GUILTY .
FIFTH DAY. TUESDAY, JUNE 3.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1303.
JOHN GEORGE JELF, alias GEORGE JELF
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of March , 1 bill of exchange for payment of, and value of 1000l. , the property of
James Hall
; against the Statute.
MR. BRODRICK conducted the prosecution.

JAMES HALL. I live at Bexley-place, Greenwich. In February last, in consequence of an advertisement in the newspaper, I wrote a letter (see No. 1) directed to S. S., Albany, and on the 18th of March I received this answer,(see No. 2); my servant brought it to me, and next day I went to No. 20, Dover-street, Piccadilly, I saw the prisoner, who stated that his name was Jelf, and having other business at Greenwich he had called at my house the day before, respecting the letter I had written in answer to an advertisement - that he should have noticed it before, but he had been into the country to fetch his wife: he said he had some trust-money to advance, which would not be required for eight months for the purposes of the trust, and asked what sum I required. I said, "We will say for the present about 1000l." and I proposed to deposit deeds of freeholds as a security. He said there was another gentleman to be consulted, and said "If you have a bill, Mr. Hall, it will be more satisfactory, as there will then be two persons as security." I happened to have in my pocket a bill drawn by myself on Mr. Richard Delves, of Tunbridge-wells, for 1000l., and accepted by him payable at Sir James Esdaile's - it was dated 5th of December, 1827, at twelve months date. I handed it over to him, he said "This will do; will you leave it with me that I may make enquiries respecting the responsibility of yourself and Mr. Delves." I had endorsed the bill when it first came into my possession, but that did not occur to me at the time; it was payable to my order; I handed it to him and left it with him.

Q. Was it left with him for any purpose whatever than what you have stated? A. It was left for inquiry only - no advance whatever was made on it - this was on Wednesday; he appointed for me to call on the Friday, to hear the report as to the inquiry. I called on Friday; he then stated that he had not had time to make the inquiries, and appointed for me to call again; he gave me at that time this memorandum. (read.) "5th December, 1827, at twelve months after date 1000l., signed J. Hall. To Mr. R. Delves, Tunbridge Wells. Sir, received the above bill, to do the needful or return, 21st March, 1828." On my arriving at home that day I found this note, which I should have received on the Thursday, (see No. 3.) On the Monday before I had received this note from him,(see No. 4.) - On the Monday or Tuesday following I called at his house, as from some information I had become desirous of having the bill - I saw him, and he stated that he had given it to a friend, who would call on me to ascertain if it was my signature, and to make inquiries - that he would call at nine o'clock in the morning or five o'clock in the afternoon of the next day, and requested me to be at home - he did not say who his friend was - I remained at home, nobody called - I called at his house on Wednesday but did not see him - I called on Thursday night, Mrs. Jelf said he was not at home - I said I would wait till he returned - I waited and saw him - he came into the room, but I observed his hat was on the table all the time, which induced me to wait for the purpose of getting the bill back - I stated that Mr. Delves was in town, and would give other bills for it - he said the bill was not in his possession, but he would meet me at Mr. Isaacs, his attorney, next day, and return it. I went to Mr. Isaacs but he did not come - I did not see him again - I received this letter from him,(see No. 5) - I have never received a shilling from him - I do not know what he means by the "small balance" - I published bills describing his person, and offering 50l. reward for him - I have not recovered the bill, or any proceeds for it - I enquired at the Albany and found there was a Mr. Simms there, a ship-broker, but nobody of the prisoner's description.
Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. You found the porter of the Albany received letters from the prisoner? A. Yes. Mr. Delves is not here - I did not take the bill in my pocket to get him to discount it.

Q. Did he not on the Friday take the bill out of his pocket, and offer to return it to you? A. No, he did not; I demanded it on two occasions - he said, at the second interview, that it would he more convenient if the bill was exchanged for small ones, as they would be more easily negotiated - I wrote a note about bills of 200l. and 300l. in order to get the hill back, as I had seen Mr. Roe, of Marlborough-street, on the subject, and after what I heard I should have had no dealings with him; if he had offered me 1000l. I do not believe I should have taken it and left the bill - I never breakfasted with him.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. When you inquired at the Albany and found letters had been left there, had you ascertained whether the person was known there? A. The porter said he knew nothing about him, but he had asked him to take in letters for him - I never intended to part with my bill - he never produced it to me after I gave it to him.

COURT. Q. Your purpose was to obtain a certain sum of money? A. Yes; he was to have had the deeds and the bill; the offer I made to get other bills was in order to get it back; Mr. Delves is a good respectable man.

WILLIAM CREED
. I live in Abchurch-lane. The prisoner was apprehended by my young man a few days after the bills were published; he was brought to my house - I asked why he had not given the bill up; he said he had parted with it to a gentleman who had gone to Newmarket - I have known Mr. Hall many years.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. What is Hall? A. A wine-merchant , at Margate, had several shares in the Margate pier, and I believe he has some in the Navigation Company; I do not known of his having any landed estate, and know nothing about his emergencies; I went with him to Esdaile's, to stop payment of the bill; they knew Mr. Delves very well. I belong to a society for the suppression of swindlers, and am a tailor; I was once indicted for perjury, but the prosecutor was so condescending as to withdraw the indictment without any application.

GEORGE CORNFORD
. I apprehended the prisoner on the 25th of April, at Knightsbride; I tapped him on the shoulder, and said, "How do you do, Mr. Jelf?" he said,"My name is not Jelf - it is Simms;" I told him it was Jelf, and he must come with me - he said he would not, he must go the other way; I said I would not allow him - he then took my arm, and we walked on; as we came along I asked him about Mr. Hall; he said he knew Mr. Hall - that he had parted with the bill, and how could I think that a person in his circumstances could have it.

JOHN NOWELL
. I am porter at the Albany. I know Mr. Simms, a ship-broker; the prisoner came to the lodge door, and said, "If a letter comes directed S. S., will you have the goodness to take charge of it;" I did not know him - he did not live in the Albany; I received a few letters, and afterwards told him it was against my order to take in letters, except for gentlemen connected with the building; he said, "Very well, I will direct them to my solicitor, in the Temple." I had four or five letters; several persons called to make inquiries - I told them I knew nothing about him.
The following are the Letters referred to.
No. 1. 4th of March, 1828.

SIR, - Having just been informed by a friend of an advertisement relative to a sum of money to be advanced, I beg leave to mention, that I have occasion for an advance of 2000l. or 3000l.; shall be obliged by a line, appointing an interview, addressed to my residence, Bexley-place, Greenwich.
JAMES HALL.
No. 2. 18th of March.

SIR, - I waited on you in consequence of a letter addressed to my clerk, Mr. Simms, at the Albany; having some business in Greenwich to-day: if you will call on me from eleven to two o'clock to-morrow, I will make a point of being in the way, and conferring with you on the subject of your letter.
I am, Sir, your obedient servant, J. JELF.
No. 20, Dover-street, Piccadilly.
No. 3.
Mr. Jelf's compliments to Mr. Hall, and will thank him to call on Saturday instead of Friday.
No. 4.

DEAR SIR, - My friend is making some inquiries at Tunbridge, and on Thursday I shall be able to speak to you definitively; I shall be at Greenwich on Thursday afternoon, and will be at your house about five o'clock. J. JELF.
No. 5. Dover, 2d of April. 1828.

SIR, - Business of great importance obliges me to leave for France, for a short time, and I am this moment getting into the steam-packet for Calais; on my return I will call upon you, and give you the small balance which may be due to you upon the bill. J. JELF.

Prisoner's Defence. Mr. Law left the bill with me to get discounted; he has partaken of my bounty repeatedly - I was obliged to leave home, respecting some persons who had given me bills, and who have since fled; as to the balance I allude to. he was to have had 200l. or 300l. in cash, which was all he seemed to require; this arrangement would have been settled, but when I found that in my absence my character had been aspersed, and improper language used to my wife, I certainly refused to relinquish the bill till satisfaction had been made for injuries so serious, and conduct so detestable; if proper satisfaction had been made he would not have found me backward in fulfilling my intentions.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Transported for Seven Years .

1304.
THOMAS JEFFRIES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 20 quarters of malt, value 60l. , the goods of
John Lyall
and others.

In October Session Parsons and others were convicted of this offence; the prisoner was included in the indictment, - as none of the witnesses could identify him as being concerned, Mr. Churchill withdrew from the prosecution.
NOT GUILTY .

1305.
ROBERT HUGHES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of May , 1 carpenter's rule, value 2s. , the goods of
William Nosworthy
.

WILLIAM NOSWORTHY. I am a carpenter . The prisoner came to me last Saturday, and asked for a job; I said I did not know of one - he stood at the bench, and asked for something to drink - I said I did not want anything, and desired him to walk away; he stood muttering something; I went to the end of the bench. and saw him go out; he was shuffling at the side of his thigh - I went after him, and said, "You have my rule;" "I have" says he, and he gave it me.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I was rather in liquor.
NOT GUILTY .

1307.
WILLIAM WALTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 2 live fowls, price 5s. , the property of
David Brown
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1308.
MARY WARREN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 1 gown, value 2s. , the goods of
Robert Alexander Jones
.

ELIZABETH JONES
. I am the wife of Robert Alexander Jones - we live in White Hart-court, Castle-street
. I lost a gown from behind my room door up one pair of stairs - there was a child ten years old in the room, who gave an alarm, and the prisoner was taken in Cecil-court.

JANET MURRAY
. I saw the prisoner leave the house; a man stopped her, and I saw this gown found on her.(Property produced and sworn to.)

RICHARD MILLER
. I took the prisoner.
GUILTY . Aged 42.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1309.
WILLIAM WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 2 asses, price 8l. , the property of
Thomas Fisher
.

THOMAS FISHER. I live at Watford. I keep asses, and supply families with milk ; I lost two asses on Thursday night or Friday morning last from Watford-heath
; they had been accustomed to be turned out there for about a month - I had had one of these about five weeks; the other about six weeks; they were with four others of mine; I saw them all safe on Thursday night at nine o'clock; I know nothing of the prisoner; I saw them again on Friday evening and knew them to be mine.

HENRY FOX
. I am toll-keeper at Westbourne-green gate; I saw the prisoner on Friday morning, at half-past four o'clock, riding on one of these asses, and another person with him on another; the other man came and offered me 2d., but the toll being 4d. I refused to take it; he said sooner than pay 4d. he would go back, which they did; the prisoner was riding the smallest of the two asses. A gentleman named Roach came at eleven o'clock and asked if I had seen any asses; I told him - I saw the prisoner near the gate the same afternoon and knew him to be the man; he was secured; I have seen the donkeys since, and know them to be the same they were riding; I had not known the prisoner before.

RICHARD HARTLEY WALL
. The prisoner was brought to the Police-office on Friday with the donkeys, which the prosecutor claimed; I was directed to take charge of them, and I have taken care that no other person should have access to them; they are at the door.
THOMAS FISHER. They are my property.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

1310.
ELIZABETH THOMAS
and
EDWARD FERNLEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of May , 2 shirts, value 15s.; 1 hammock, value 5s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 palm, value 8d., and 1 needle case, value 1d. , the goods of
John Francisco
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1311.
MARGARET LUSH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of May , 1 gown, value 5s. , the goods of
John Harigan
.

MARY HARIGAN
. I am the wife of John Harigan, and live in George-gardens, Drury-lane
. On the 28th of May I brought this gown from Whitechapel, and laid it on my bed; the prisoner was with me; she came down while I went to get a candle, and when I returned she was gone and the gown too; I knew her by sight, she asked me if she should come down with me, and I said Yes.

JOHN PROSSER
. I live at a pawnbroker's, in Gray's-inn-lane; I took in this gown of the prisoner on Thursday afternoon.
MARY HARIGAN. This is my gown; I never gave it to her to pawn; when I took her on Friday she threw herself on her knees, and took her oath that she knew nothing about the gown.
JOHN HARIGAN. I have known the prisoner by sight about a month; I never allowed her to pawn anything or treated her.

THOMAS SMEE
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner and asked her if she had pawned the gown; she said Yes, but did not say where; I found by the prosecutor that it was at Mr. Creed's, in Gray's-inn-lane; I took the prisoner there and they identified her; she was very much intoxicated, and I think she did not do it willingly.

Prisoner's Defence. On Wednesday evening the prosecutrix came to my basket, where I sell things in the street; she asked if I would have any thing to drink; I said Yes; we went to a house and got a little in our heads; I went to her room; her husband was in bed tipsy; I had lent her 8 1/2d; she said she had a gown she would pawn and give me the money, as I could not go to market; it was too late that night; I took it to pawn on Thursday.

MARY HARIGAN re-examined. Q. How came you to know where to find the gown? A. I went from one shop to another; I met a woman with a load on her head, who asked if I had lost a gown; I said Yes; she said, "Go to the top of Gray's-inn-lane, to a little shop, and you will find it."
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1312.
JOHN JOLLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of May , 1 pair of trowsers, value 9s. , the goods of
Haufman Samuel
.

MOSES HARRIS
. I am in the employ of Haufman Samuel. These trowsers were at his door in Graces's-alley
, between eleven and twelve o'clock on the 5th of May; the prisoner came into the shop and asked if I had a fustian jacket; I said No; he took the trowsers and ran away; the officer took him about fifty yards off; when I got out the trowsers were lying on the ground.

THOMAS SMITH
. I am an officer. I was going by and met the prisoner; I took him and he dropped the trowsers.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I was going to my work, and the trowsers were dropped by somebody else.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Three Months .

1311.
SARAH HILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of October , 2 gowns, value 12s.; 4 caps, value 2s.; 3 pair of stockings, value 18d., and 3 napkins, value 1s. , the goods of
William Anderson
.

MARY ANN ANDERSON
. I am the wife of William Anderson; he is a seaman ; we live in Bedford-court, Catherine-street
. I took the prisoner in out of charity - I lost the articles stated out of my room; I was ill with a bad arm; I gave a silk handkerchief off my arm, and asked her to give me a cotton one, which she did; my husband came to bed at half-past nine o'clock; I said to the prisoner, "Why do you stop up so late," as I am in the habit of going out at two o'clock in the morning - she made an excuse that she was going to wash some towels and asked me for some dirty linen, saying she would have them all ready in the morning - I laid still, with my arm up in bed; I heard no more of her till about eleven o'clock, when I saw her go out with a bundle - I said, "What makes you stop up so late?" she made no answer, but went out of the room, and never returned; I missed the property soon after - I did not see her again till she was at Bow-street; I never allowed her to take anything away.
GUILTY . Aged 48.
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1314.
LOUISA HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of May , 1 watch, value 10s. , the goods of
Richard Harris
.

RICHARD HARRIS. I am a waterman , and attend coaches ; I live in Bulstrode-mews, Marylebone-lane
. I had broken the glass of my watch, and put it into a box in my room: and on the 26th of May I opened the box, and missed the watch; I had kept the box locked, and had the key of it - the prisoner is my daughter; I met her in Bond-street on Friday last, and challenged her with it; she gave me up the duplicate of it - she is a bad girl, and comes home when she likes; I never allowed her to pawn that or anything else.

HUGH GAULEY
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a watch pawned with me on the 27th of May by a female, in the name of Louisa Harris; I gave this duplicate for it; I cannot say that it was the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I asked him to let me in, and he would not; I did it for want - I had not had a bit of bread for three days.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1315.
LOUISA HARRIS
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 1 apron, value 18d. , the goods of
Elizabeth Simpson
.

HANNAH CHIVRALL
. I know Elizabeth Simpson; she is an old woman, and lives in Conway-court
- the prisoner used to come to see a person there; the prisoner's father produced the duplicate of the apron, and Mrs. Simpson sent to me to see if it was her's; I know it to be her property.

JAMES FRANCIS THOMPSON
. I am shopman to Jones and Motts, pawnbrokers. I took in this apron from the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

RICHARD HARRIS
. When I challenged her with robbing me, she gave me the duplicate of this apron and the other likewise.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years, to commence from the expiration of her former sentence .

1316.
JAMES ASTON
&
CORNELIUS GLANDFIELD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a man unknown
, from his person .

CHARLES GEORGE VINCENT
. I am a constable. On Sunday week, about half-past nine o'clock in the evening, I was in the City-road
; I saw a person, who I believe was Glandfield, take a handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, and give it to Aston, who put it under the tail of his coat, and was crossing the road, I went up to him, and took him - I put my hand down by his side, where I thought I had seen the handkerchief and endeavoured to take it from him; I felt his hand move, but did not see the handkerchief go from him; Mr. Hall came up, and asked if I had lost anything - I said I had not, but another person had picked a gentleman's pocket of his handkerchief, and given it to the prisoner; he said he had seen something thrown away, and ran and got this handkerchief - I believe Glandfield was the personwho took it; I went the next morning, and took him in Chequer-place.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Was it not rather dark? A. Yes, but there was a light opposite me - a person named Toole was with me - I ordered Toole to go after the gentleman.

THOMAS TOOLE
. I was with Vincent; I told him I saw the two prisoners in company trying pockets - we followed them, and saw them go towards a gentleman; Glandfield took the handkerchief from him, and gave it to Aston; I said, "They have got it" - he crossed the road, and took Aston; I was going after Glandfield, but he said, Go, tell the gentleman - I went, but could not overtake him; I knew where Glandfield lived, and told Vincent.

WILLIAM HALL
. I am inspector of the watch. I was standing at the Star public-house; I saw Vincent collar Aston; and while he had hold of him, I saw Aston throw the handkerchief down - I asked Vincent if he had lost anything; he said Aston had received a handkerchief; I told him to hold him fast - I went to the place where the handkerchief fell; a little boy took it up and gave it to me.

TIMOTHY DONOVAN
. I picked up this handkerchief; I did not see who threw it down.
ASTON'S Defence. There were two or three men in the road; the officer collared me and took me.
GLANDFIELD'S Defence. I was in bed at half past eight o'clock.

ASTON -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

GLANDFIELD -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Confined Three Months and
Whipped .

1317.
SOPHIA FITZPATRICK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 3 sovereigns, the monies of
John Butcher
, from his person .

JOHN BUTCHER. I am a watchman . On Thursday last I was in Bagnigge-wells-Road
, between five and six o'clock in the afternoon; the prisoner came up to me, took hold of my arm, put her hand in my coat pocket and took out three sovereigns, rolled up in a dirty piece of cloth - I felt her hand in my pocket - I put my hand into my pocket and missed my money - I followed her into the Wells, but she had turned a corner and I missed her; I came out, went round and went in again; I then met her and charged her with robbing me of three sovereigns; I gave her in charge of Barnes, who took one sovereign from her hand; an officer took her into a room and found two more sovereigns on her; she had laid hold of my arm - my money was safe just before I met her.

JOSEPH HENRY BARNES
. I am an appraiser and was at Bagnigge-wells. Butcher said he had lost a sovereign; I took hold of the prisoner's hand; some persons came up and wanted to let her go; I saw her hand behind her, took hold of it, and took the sovereign out of it; the officer came up and found the other two sovereigns and a piece of rag; she said "It makes no odds to me whether he gave me a sovereign or a shilling." I said "Where are the other two?" She said she had no more.

AUSTIN HARLE
. I am an officer. I was sent for - the prisoner said nothing to the charge; I found two sovereigns and a dirty rag on her.
JOHN BUTCHER. This is like my piece of rag.
Prisoners' Defence. He asked me to accompany him to the gardens, and when there he asked me to go with him, and he would give me three shillings; he gave me this and I found it was three sovereigns.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Life .

1318.
EDWARD COOKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of May , 9 lbs. weight of horse-hair, value 35s.; 1 coat, value 10s.; 2 pairs of pantaloons, value 17s.; 1 waistcoat, value 18d.; and 1 handkerchief, value 1d. the goods of
John Salter
.

JOSEPH LLOYD
. I am a watchman. I met the prisoner on Sunday evening, the 4th of May, about ten o'clock, at the top of East-street, Hoxton, about two hundred yards from Mr. Salter's with a bundle - I asked what was in it, he said some washing; I took it from under his arm, and seeing some hair and the rest of these articles in it, I took him to the watch-house.

JOHN SALTER. I am a horse-hair manufacturer , and live at Hoxton
. On Sunday, the 4th of May, I went out at four o'clock in the afternoon, leaving my door on the single lock; I came home about eleven o'clock at night - I had drunk rather more than had done me good; the door was locked - I went in and went up to bed - my wife perceived the things disturbed; we had left nobody at home; we looked and missed these articles from the first-floor front room.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Had you been drinking before you left home? A. I had taken a little - I know I pulled the door too.

CHARLES CONSTABLE
. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house; I searched him and found some picklock keys, a crow-bar, and phosphorus box on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had been drinking - I heard a cry, ran out to see what it was, and these things lay in the road - I took them up.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

1319.
JOHN HALE
and
JOHN KENT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of May
, 6 bushels of oats and chaff mixed, value 8s., the goods of
Hugh McIntosh
, their master ; and
WILLIAM HAYNES
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to have been stolen .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM BANNISTER
. I am clerk to Hugh McIntosh, who is employed at the New Palace - Hale and Kent drove his team of horses
.

THOMAS HINDER
. I am in Hugh McIntosh's employ. I had to drive the horses from St. James's-park to Richmond, to fetch turf to beautify the gardens; the ostler puts the horse corn out in sacks every morning at the stable-yard at Westminster; I was employed for eight days going to Richmond, till the 14th of May - we had about three bushels of chaff and corn every morning to feed fourteen horses. On the 8th of May Hale and Kent gave a sack of corn to Haynes, at the Old George public-house, Brompton; he gave him all that the ostler had given out for the horses; Haynes was at the stable - I saw him give Hale half-a-crown, and Kent told me hehad another; I should think it was worth about 5s.; Mr. McIntosh's name was on the cart - Haynes took the corn into the stable and stowed it; he returned the sack directly, and they went away; when Kent heard that Mr. McIntosh had heard of it, he came to me and said he would give me three sovereigns if I would say nothing about it - I told of it last Saturday week, not before.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you mention the three sovereigns at Bow-street? A. Yes - I do not know whether my evidence was read over to me; I believe it was; I did not see what was in the sack - it was given out to us as corn; I abused Kent, because the corn was not given to the horses - I had no money; they offered me beer several times, but I refused it - I had one pint with them; I did not like to make a disturbance about it, as I had only been there a few days - I had no quarrel with them about a jacket, it was with another servant; I did not mention it till after that - we had the nose-bag full for the horses to eat.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Had you any quarrel with them? A. No; the horses had nothing more than was in the corn-bin - Colopy was with me.

JOHN COLOPY
. I was employed to drive a team for Mr. McIntosh. I saw Hale and Kent give Haynes two sacks of corn, at the George, at Brompton; he took it into the stable, and brought the sacks out again.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see the sacks filled? A. Yes - 5s. 6d each would be a fair price for them; I knew it was for the horses - I did not like to tell master, but I did three days after; I only see the foreman once a week - I had part of the beer which was bought with the money - I cannot say how much I drank; they were taken up about a week after.

THOMAS POWELL
. I am ostler at Mr. McIntosh's stable. I gave out two sacks, each containing three bushels, every day for the horses; and did so on the 8th of May - it was chaff and corn mixed; Mr. McIntosh's name was on the cart.
Cross-examined. Q. How long did the men remain in the employ? A. I do not know - I knew nothing of it till master told me.

RICHARD STARKEY
. I know this corn - this mixture is worth 4s. or 5s. each sack.
KENT'S Defence. The witness is a false man - he lost a jacket, and said if we did not give it up he would go and tell of the robbery which he never saw.
NOT GUILTY .

1320.
JOHN HALE
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of May
, 6 bushels of oats and chaff mixed, value 8s , the goods of
Hugh McIntosh
; and
WILLIAM HAYNES
was again indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing it to have been stolen .

No Evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1321.
THOMAS DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of May
, 3 bushels of oats and chaff mixed , the goods of
Hugh McIntosh
; and
WILLIAM HAYNES
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to have been stolen .

No Evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1322.
DOMINICK FEELEY
was indicted for
bigamy .
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

SARAH SOUTH
. I am a widow, and live on Saffron-hill. The prisoner lived with me - he was married to
Jane Cowley
; they lived together at my house - they went out to be married and slept at my house after that; she went by his name, and they lived together for five or six months - the prisoner asked me to drink with him and his wife; I am sure he called her his wife.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Was it not a Mrs. Hyde you saw? A. No - her name was Cowley; she is outside the Court now; they left me to keep a public-house, but I have not seen her for ten or twelve years till lately.

JOSEPH MOULD
. I am parish-clerk of St. Andrew, Holborn. I have the register of the marriage of Jane Cowley and
Thomas Feeley
, by licence, on the 22d of February, 1812.

CHARLES FISHER SAVIGNEY
. I am beadle of Holborn, and know Jane Feeley. In November, 1812, I apprehended the prisoner for deserting his wife; she applied for relief to the parish - I relieved her; she is now at the door - the prisoner acknowledged her as his wife, and was committed to prison.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you seen much of his wife since? A. No - not till latterly.

SARAH GRIFFITHS
. I am a widow - the prisoner was clerk to my late husband, who kept the Cooper's Arms, public-house, Crown-street, Finsbury. I was married to the prisoner at Shoreditch Church
on Shrove Tuesday; he passed as a single man for some time before we were married.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you and your husband did not live on the best of terms? A. Why I found he had another wife, but I would not appear against him; he died six years ago - I made him support me, for he had 2000l. of money; I have not been reluctant to prosecute the prisoner - I never lived with a Mr. Chippendale.
Q. How long did you live with the prisoner before you married him? A. That is not a fair question; I did not live with him; he paid me a sovereign a week.

Q. Did you not cohabit with him? A. Why as many of the first ladies in the land have done I did do it; I knew he had a wife; when I found that out we parted beds, but lived together for about a month - I discovered it six weeks ago; I have no children - he had no money with me. I have been arrested - the prisoner owes me nearly 200l.; I keep the Coopers' Arms now; the license is not in the prisoner's name.

GEORGE YARROW
. I am clerk of Shoreditch; I have a register of the prisoner's marriage to S. Griffiths on the 19th of February , 1828. - (read.)
Prisoner's Defence. This is a complete conspiracy against me - this woman will swear though a nine inch board - she owes me 100l. now.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Confined Three Months .

1323.
JOHN MACINTOSH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 1 box, value 6s.; 4 coats, value 7l.; 5 pairs of trousers, value 2l.; 10 shirts, value 50s.; 12 pairs of stockings, value 24s.; 12 handkerchiefs, value 1l., and 8 waistcoats, value 1l. , the goods of
James Mackenzie
.

JAMES MACKENZIE. I am a ladies' shoemaker . Icame to town on Tuesday, and left my box on board the smack at Hoares' wharf
, in care of the steward; when I returned on Thursday, one box, containing these articles was gone; some persons on board gave me information - Crighton took us to a house in Rosemary-lane, where the prisoner lived; the people were out - I went for a constable, he came and found the box in the back room; it had been broken open, and several things taken out.

DAVID CRIGHTON
. I am a porter, and work at Hoares' wharf. I carried a yellow trunk by the prisoner's order, from the vessel to the White Swan public-house, Rosemary-lane; he went there with me - he said it was his own - I was on the wharf waiting for a job; I am sure he said it was his own, and he said he was a passenger in that vessel, the Forfairshire; I was called again at eight o'clock that night, and went with the prosecutor to find it.

JOSEPH KING
. I am a porter. The prisoner applied to me on Thursday afternoon last, to carry a box from the White Swan; I took it to a house in Brown's-buildings, Princes street, and left it there - he said it was his box. I afterwards went with the prosecutor, who claimed the same box - there was a rope round it, and it appeared locked.

SARAH HAWKINS
. I live in Brown's-buildings; the prisoner was a friend of my husband's; he called on Thursday, and asked me to let him leave this box in my place, which I did; the prosecutor came and took it.

JOHN FORRESTER
. I am an officer. I found the box in Brown's-buildings, with some articles in it.

CHARLES WALLER
. I apprehended the prisoner in Rosemary-lane, and found a shirt, trousers, coat, and waistcoat, on him - he was dressed in them, and his own coat was left in the box, which had been broken open with a chisel or hatchet.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I expected a box from Scotland; I had been drinking rather freely, and thought this was mine - the linen is marked as my own.
GUILTY . Aged 52.
Transported for Seven Years .
First London Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1324.
HENRY GREENLEY
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Maxwell Windle
, Esq. on the 4th of January , at the Middle Temple
, and stealing therein, 1 cape of a great coat, value 6d.; 6 pairs of trousers, value 36s.; 5 coats, value 30s.; 6 waistcoats, value 6s.; 1 great coat, value 5s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 6s.; 2 pairs of gloves, value 6d.; 1 pair of socks, value 3s.; 1 wooden box, value 1s.; 1 syringe, value 5s.; 1 tea-caddy, value 6s.; 2 tea-ladles, value 4s.; 1 tea-spoon, value 4s., and 1 canvass-bag, value 1s., his property .
MR. EVANS conducted the prosecution.

MARY BARKER
. I am laundress to Mr. Windle. I locked up his chambers, which are in the Middle Temple, on Friday the 4th of January; he had gone out of town a few days before - I had gone there every day, except Sunday; I went there again on the 5th of January, about four o'clock in the afternoon - I found the outer door only on one lock, and the other door open, the blinds were drawn down, and the lamp was on the floor; it was in a very different state to what I had left it on the 4th - I looked round and was rather frightened, but did not know whether Mr. Windle had been there or not; I locked the chambers and went away - I went again on the next day, which was Sunday, a little after three o'clock, to look more particularly - the first thing I then saw was one of the drawers of the office table was broken open; I looked farther, and found all the drawers were broken open but two, which had not been locked, and the cellaret was broken open; I missed a tea-caddy, a brown silk umbrella, a clothes-bag, and a key, which were left at the chambers; I have since seen the caddy in Mr. Windle's possession, and the clothes-bag at Worship-street - I found a crow-bar and a chisel in the chambers; I gave them to the porter, and a gentleman who I fetched to the chambers- the outer door had not been broken; the key went in as easily as when I left it, but was only locked once - I had locked it twice.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you positive of that? A. Yes; I remarked, as I did not mean to go again that day that I had locked it safe - I found it singly locked on the Saturday; I double locked it on the Friday - I found the cupboards and drawers open, and the foul linen on the floor; I did not examine minutely that day, being alarmed and thinking Mr. Windle might have been there unknown to me - I made no more inquiry that day; I noticed it more on Sunday, when I went there to see if I could find Mr. Windle; I did not look for the key on Saturday - I locked the door when I came out; I went on Sunday to Mr. Tattersal's in Bloomsbury-square, and told him of it - I never saw the prisoner till he was taken up some months after; I heard he had been taken and was liberated - I have been a laundress four or five years.

MR. EVANS. Q. Did you send to Mr. Tattersal on the Saturday? A. Yes, but he was not at his chambers; I went to his house on Sunday, and found him - he is a friend of Mr. Windle's; I attend to three other gentlemen's chambers.

ROBERT LOCK
. I am a constable. On Friday the 4th of January, between five and six o'clock in the afternoon, I was going up Whitecross-street, and saw the prisoner crossing the road; he crossed Whitecross-street, went up a turning, and knocked at a backdoor; I followed him, as he seemed in a hurry, and passed him two or three yards - I then saw him turn back, and go into Whitecross-street again; I lost sight of him for about a minute and a half. I then saw him come across, and go into the front door of a house with this bag - I followed him in directly, and asked what he had got there; he said his father's clothes - I said that would not satisfy me, he must go with me to the watch-house: I took him there, and then said, "How did you say you got these things?" He said, "I met a gentleman in Holborn, who employed me to carry this bag:" I asked if he knew the gentleman; he said, "No:" I said, "Do you know what is in the bag;" he said No; I said "I must know;" I looked in and found all these articles - I have kept most of them ever since, but not all; I searched him and found these keys on him, and thinking one was not a right key, I said I should detain him - I looked into his hat and found some handkerchiefs; he was taken to Worship-street and examined three times, and then discharged as no owner was found.

Cross-examined. Q. Was he held to bail? A. No; hewas at full liberty - he knew he was discharged, because I could not find the owner; he was taken again in three or four months - he was at liberty till then; he knew he was liable to be taken if the owner was found.
MR. EVANS. Q. Do you recollect when you found the owner? A. I think about a week after he was discharged - the prosecutor came down to me; I then searched for him many a night and day.

MAXWELL WINDLE, ESQ. These articles are all my property; I was out of town on the 4th of January; I left them in my chamber in the Middle Temple, where I reside when in town: I rent the chambers - they are entirely my own - I sleep there.

JAMES BROWN
. I am an officer of Worship-street. I apprehended the prisoner in a room in George-street, Shoreditch, on the 9th of May, about half-past six o'clock in the morning: I told him it was for Mr. Windle's robbery; he said, "It is of no use - I know I must go with you;" I had seen him the night before, in the skittle-ground of a public-house in Plough-yard, Shoreditch, but he made his escape. I found two skeleton-keys in his room.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you call these skeleton-keys? A. Yes - they are skeleton-keys for Bramah's locks; I got them from a young woman who was in bed with him. I have been an officer nearly fifteen years.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down Holborn on the 4th of January; a gentleman came and asked me to carry this bundle, and said he would give me a shilling; I followed him down Whitecross-street, when I was shoved into a shop by Lock, and taken; I had four hearings, and was discharged.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 21. (See page 618.)

1325.
JOHN BARKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 1 coat, value 1s.; 1 waistcoat, value 6d.; 1 knife, value 6d.; 1 sixpence, 2 pennies, and 1 halfpenny, the property of
Jonathan Fitzpatrick
, from his person .

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY .
Whipped and Discharged .

1326.
THOMAS LEWIS STYLES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 gold neck-chain, value 6l., the goods of
Thomas Dobson
and others, his masters, in the dwelling-house of the said Thomas Dobson .

HENRY GLOVER
. The prisoner has been shopman to Mr. Thomas Dobson, and others, jewellers , of Leadenhall-street
, for about seven weeks. On the 11th of April, as I went to a back door, I picked up a small coral necklace; I made strict inquiry about it of the prisoner and every person in the house, but could get no information; in about an hour the prisoner came to me, and said, "Mr. Glover, I am sorry anybody should be blamed for my errors, as it respects that coral necklace; I dropped it myself:" he said he had a commission from his mother to get a necklace of that description for his sister and he had taken it to show her, and on Monday he should return it, or pay the money; I said it was a thing he had no right to do, and sent for Mr. Dobson into the warehouse; I then said Styles had said he had dropped the necklace, and that he wished to show it to his mother; I should have said he was about to leave us; we thought it prudent to have him searched, and sent for an officer: when the officer came, he put his hand into his pocket, and pulled out a variety of articles of his employer's property: he delivered up the key of his trunk, in which were found other articles mentioned in another indictment; a duplicate of the gold neck-chain was found in a pocket-book, on his person - he said it was our property.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. All he said was, that it was your's? A. Yes, I am one of the partners.

THOMAS EMBERSON
. I am a pawnbroker, and have a gold neck-chain, pawned by the prisoner, on the 7th of April, for 4l. - that is nearly the value.

GEORGE FITCH
. I took him in charge.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Of stealing to the value of 80s. only.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1327.
ISAAC GRAVES
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Nathaniel Jerrom
, on the 18th of May , putting him in fear and taking from his person and against his will 2 half-crowns, his property .

NATHANIEL JERROM. I am a tailor . On Saturday morning the 18th of May, between twelve and one o'clock, I was coming home from the Borough, and in Bishopsgate-street
I saw Mitchell sitting on a step; I helped her up, and she asked me to give her a glass of gin; I said it was late; she took me to where she knew that she could get it; but before I could get into the house the prisoner seized me by the right arm and Mitchell had hold of my left; put his hand into my right-hand pocket, and took out two half-crowns; my hat fell off; I got up and tried to escape; he struck me a violent blow on the back of my head; it cut my head - I am certain of his person; he stood by me for two minutes; he was not apprehended till Sunday night.

JOHN BROWN
. Between twelve and one o'clock in the morning of Saturday, the 18th of May, the prosecutor came home and described the prisoner; I knew him well by the description, and told him to come to me in the evening - I took him to the Black Raven, public-house, Bishopsgate-street, and asked if he could point out the man; he pointed to the prisoner and said, "This is the man I am certain."

SARAH MITCHELL
. I met the prosecutor; I had hold of his left arm when the prisoner turned his right-hand pocket inside out - I saw him do it, but did not see him take any thing; I am certain of his person; it was not him who struck him.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in Angel-alley and heard a cry of Watch! I turned back and heard a gentleman had been robbed of two half-crowns - I went straight home.
GUILTY . Aged 20.

Of stealing from the person only. -
Transported for Life .

1328.
JOHN WESTON
and
JAMES WESTON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , 1 phial of Cayenne-pepper, value 1s., and 1 pot of tamarinds, value 6d. , the goods of
William Dadds
, and another.

WILLIAM DADDS. I am a grocer , and live in Leadenhall-street
, in partnership with Mr. Eding. On the 27th of April, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I was in the counting-house, Stevens came in and said, our window was cut - I ran out; Stevens said, "Follow me;" I called two men - we pursued the prisoners andtook them; we found this property on John Weston, about eighteen doors from my house; it was safe, and the glass secure half an hour before.

JOHN STEVENS
. About eleven o'clock on the 27th of April, I saw the prisoners near the window; I saw Jones with a knife cutting the putty - I crossed over, and immediately they broke the window; James cut the window - John was close to him, holding a bag over his arm - I went and told Mr. Dadds, who came out, and we took them; I am certain of their persons - they were taken in five minutes; I never lost sight of them.

THOMAS GREY
. I am an officer. I found this bottle and pot of tamarinds in John's pocket, and this knife with putty on it; the putty appeared quite fresh cut - I found on James a sack.
JOHN WESTON'S Defence. I was standing above a yard from him, the knife was not out of my pocket, I passed the window and picked these things up.

JOHN WESTON -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

JAMES WESTON -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Six Months .

1329.
WILLIAM MILLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of April , 2 yards of twilled cotton, value 1s., the goods of
John Clark
, his master .
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

DANIEL FORRESTER
. I am an officer. On the evening of the 22d of April, I watched Mr. Clark's warehouse, and saw the prisoner come out; I followed him down East Smithfield
, where he joined a woman, and went into a liquor-shop; I followed him, pulled off his hat, and found these two pieces of calico - he said, "You don't mean to take me for this, we will have a drop of something to drink; you don't know me, nor I you;" I took him to his master's counting-house, and he said, he took it to make a pair of drawers - he said this quite voluntarily.

ROBERT BYFIELD
. I am in Mr. John Clark's employ. The prisoner was brought back in custody; I did not see him until next morning - I saw the goods safe at four o'clock.(Property produced and sworn to.)

HENRY PHILLIPS
. I am in Mr. Clark's employ, and was present when the prisoner was brought back; no threat or inducement was held out to him - he said, "It is only a piece of brown cotton, which I took to make myself a pair of drawers;" the officer said, "Then you acknowledge you had it from Mr. Clark's?" he said, Yes; he has been in our employ one year and three quarters.
GUILTY . Aged 49.

Strongly recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Two Months .

1330.
WILLIAM BENTLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of May , 1 pelisse, value 6s., and 1 shawl, value 4s. , the goods of
Stephen Sandford
.

STEPHEN SANDFORD. I keep an eating-house in Duke-street
. I missed a shawl and a pelisse from my bed-room, on the 3d of May - I suspected the prisoner, and found him on the 6th of May, in custody; I did not know him before.

JOHN LAWS
. I was on duty in Newgate-street on the 5th of May; the prosecutor came and gave the prisoner into my charge.

NATHANIEL ROUTH
. I was at Guildhall when the prisoner was brought there; he was discharged, to be sent on board a ship - as I went along with him, I said, "It is a pity the man should lose his property;" he then cried, and said, he would show me where it was - he took me to the pawnbroker's; and said, he did not intend to go away without letting the man know where it was.

HENRY WHARTON
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 1st of May the prisoner pawned this pelisse, and on the 26th of April, this shawl.
Prisoner. It was all through starvation.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1331.
PETER SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of May , 2 looking-glasses, value 5s., the goods of
Arthur Wilcoxon
, and others, his masters .

ARTHUR WILCOXON. I am a looking-glass manufacturer , and live in Lombard-street
; the prisoner was in my employ for about twelve months - on the 24th of May I lost these two glasses.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. You sell a great number? A. Yes; I cannot say I have not sold them; I had a nine years character with him - I have two partners.

FRANCIS KEYS
. On the 24th of May I was watching Mr. Wilcoxon's porters out; I saw the prisoner come out, and followed him, he went into a pawnbrokers in Houndsditch, and pawned these glasses - I then followed him to Southwark-bridge and took him.

THOMAS CAPPS
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned these glasses.

JAMES FOWLER
. I went to the prisoner's lodgings and found another glass.
GUILTY . Aged 44.

Strongly recommended to Mercy -
Confined 3 months .

1332.
WILLIAM AUSTIN
and
RICHARD SAFFERY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of May , 1 gallon of porter, value 1s. 2d., the goods of
Henry Hole
, in a certain barge on the navigable river Thames
.

HENRY HOLE. I am a barge owner . On the 11th of May I had some porter on board to go to Canterbury - the prisoners were employed on board
.

SAMUEL BLYTH
. I am a Thames Police-surveyor. On the 11th of May, at 2 o'clock in the morning, I saw a light on board the Brigg barge, and saw a can handed down from the deck; I went on board and found Saffery on the deck; I said "What have you there?" He said,"Porter and a general cargo;" I went into the hold and found a spile in the porter cask - I said, "You have been spiling a cask, and I saw a can handed down;" Austin, who was below, said it was necessary to spile casks - I searched for the can, and said it was very odd I could not find it; I went down a second time with Dean, the master, and found the can under a sack, with a quantity of porter in it - I found a gimblet on Austin, and a piece of a different spile; the gimblet was wet, andfitted the hole in the cask; Austin said, "We were very dry, and thought no harm of taking a little porter."
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Does not the beer work at times? A. Yes; they then make a hole in the top of the cask, but this was in the head; their work is hard.
COURT. Q. Were they at work there? A. No.

WILLIAM CARTER WESTCOTT
. I am a cooper and examined the cask; there was a hole in the bilge and a spile in the head, where we never allow a spile to be stuck; it was not in that state when it left Messrs. Trueman and Co., my employers.

WILLIAM BELL
. I live at Messrs. Hanbury's, and filled the casks; there was no spile in them.

THOMAS MORRIS
. I was with Blyth; I saw Saffery hand the cask into the hold; I am certain he was the man: I was not above two yards from him; Austin was below.
HENRY HOLE. They were hard-working men; I am so convinced of their honesty that I will take them into my employ again.
NOT GUILTY .

1333.
CHARLES BURFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of April , 1 watch, value 3l.; 2 seals, value 18d.; 1 watch-key, value 6d.; 1 ring, value 6d.; and 1 piece of ribbon, value 1d., the goods of
John Storment
, from his person .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1334.
MARY ANN DONOVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of May , 3 sovereigns, 12 shillings and 4 sixpences, the monies of
Jonathan Wilkinson
, from his person .

JONATHAN WILKINSON. I live near Uxbridge. On Tuesday last I was in Fleet-market
with Brown; he asked me to have a glass of something; we were going to Mr. Mason's, and met the prisoner with another young woman; the prisoner asked if we would give her anything to drink; we gave her no answer; she followed us; my friend gave me a glass of gin and the prisoner one: she then asked me for one; I made her no answer - she pushed close up to me as I turned to speak to Mr. Mason, and then my purse was gone from my pocket; I said to her immediately, "You have robbed me - you have picked my pocket and got my purse and money;" she declared she had not; I said I would have her searched; I sent for an officer, and just as he came I saw the purse drop down at the counter; there was no one within a yard of her; I took it up, but the money was gone; she was taken to the watch-house; I have not recovered the money; it was all safe half an hour before, when I gave some change.

JOEL BROWN
. I was with Wilkinson at half-past six o'clock in the morning; we went into the wine-vaults; he said he had lost his purse and money - the prisoner was at his side and the other young woman was close to him; they were close to him for about ten minutes; I saw the prisoner put her hand into her bosom, take out the purse, and pass it outside her linen, between her thighs; she kept it there about three minutes and then let it fall; the other woman, who was close to her, turned round, and asked if I would accept of a glass of spirits; I refused and placed myself against the door; there were seven or eight men there; some of them went out at the other-door.

BENJAMIN KIRBY
. I am a patrol. Wilkinson gave the prisoner and another woman into my charge; I saw the purse at the prisoner's feet, and at the Compter we found 8s.6d. on her; she was very violent and saucy, and singing.

RICE PRICE
. I took her in charge; here is the purse and 8s.6d.(Purse produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. We were going to a coffee-shop; the prosecutor was selling water-cresses, and said he would treat us; he poured out a glass of gin and peppermint; he was drunk and said he had lost his money; he accused the other woman of it and then me; I never saw his purse till it was on the floor.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1335.
SAMUEL BARNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , one order for payment of and value 2l. , the property of
John Dangerfield
.

JOHN BIGGERSTAFF
. I live in Smithfield, and am a money-dealer. On the 15th of April, the prisoner presented a cheque for 2l. at my office - the payment had been stopped; I asked him how he got it - he said he found it at Temple-bar the night preceding - I gave him in charge.

JOHN DANGERFIELD. This cheque is payable to me - it was in my possession on the 14th of April; I took it about eight o'clock that morning, of Mr. Rhodes, the drawer, in Wellington-street, Strand; I had it safe about eleven o'clock, when I was on Tower-hill - I was at Limehouse-bridge
between nine and ten o'clock at night, and was knocked down and robbed of my hat and this cheque - there might be four or five men who knocked me down; the cheque was in my breeches pocket - I had been drinking.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you not drunk? A. No - nor was I sober; I could have walked home - I live at East Ham; I cannot say that I ever saw the prisoner - I was not in Fleet-street that day - Yes, I was certainly, but I did not drink till I got to Tower-hill: I went to two public-houses; I drank nothing but gin and beer - I was on Tower-hill about ten o'clock in the morning; I cannot tell what houses I went into, or at what times I drank - I was not at four public-houses; I went and stopped the cheque next morning - I was knocked down by the side of the river.
COURT. Q. Between eleven o'clock in the morning and nine at night, did you see your cheque safe? A. Yes; between four and five - I walked home that night.
Prisoner's Defence. As I was going to Temple-bar to my uncle's, I found a piece of paper; I kept it till next morning and asked the gentleman if it was payable.

JOHN BENNETT
. I am a master butcher and live at No. 10 1/2, Petticoat-lane, next door to the prisoner's parents. On Monday evening, the 14th of April I saw him at home, from five o'clock till eight; his house is about two miles from Limehouse-bridge - I saw him in the shop standing at the counter all the time.

ALFRED WOOLF
. I am a corn-merchant. I know nothing of the prisoner, but serve his brother with flour; I saw him in his brother's shop on the 14th of April, from seven till eight o'clock at night.
NOT GUILTY .
SIXTH DAY. WEDNESDAY, JUNE 4.
Second London Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1336.
CORNELIUS MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Charles Harrington Twight
, from his person .

CHARLES HARRINGTON TWIGHT. On the 16th of April, between seven and eight in the evening, I was in Smithfield
inquiring my way and felt my handkerchief drawn from my pocket; I turned round, and a woman said"A man has drawn your handkerchief from your pocket;" I saw the prisoner running; I pursued and cried Stop thief! the patrol stopped him - I had not lost sight of him; he was about five or six yards from me when I first saw him; there were some persons by his side, but none between us - he ran straight forward; a little boy picked up the handkerchief - it is the one I lost.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you able to describe the handkerchief at the watch-house? A. Yes; I was not positive whether there were any initials on it - I said it was like one I had at home.

WILLIAM SPENCER
. I am a patrol. I saw the prisoner stopped - the prosecutor was running after him; a lad gave me the handkerchief.

JOHN SPRATMAN
. I saw the prisoner running and saw him drop the handkerchief; I took it up and gave it to the officer.

GEORGE GODFREY
. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house - the prosecutor said he thought there was some yellow in the colour of the handkerchief.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1337.
JAMES MORLAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of May , 1 coat, value 3l.; 1 waistcoat, value 20s.; 1 petticoat, value 6s.; 2 frocks, value 6s.; 1 apron, value 6d.; 1 other petticoat, value 1s., and 1 shawl, value 8s. , the goods of
Thomas Jennings
.

ANN SOPHIA JENNINGS
. I am the wife of Thomas Jennings. On the 6th of May I saw this property safe in a box in my room about eight o'clock in the morning; I saw the prisoner at the bottom of the court at ten - I saw him again in my room at half-past eleven o'clock, getting out of my window; I was going into my room, and he pushed against the door - I waited some time, and saw him go from behind the door and stand in the middle of the room- I cried out, "Lord have mercy upon me;" Stephens came from the water-closet, and the prisoner made his way out at the window; I went in and shut the window, put the fastenings on it, and sent Stephens to tell my husband; I went and fetched Mr. Worrall to go into my room with me; I found my trunk broken open, and the articles stated taken from it; I saw the prisoner in about three hours.

JOHN STEVENS
. I was at Mr. Jennings'; I saw the prisoner climbing up at the window; I did not see whether he got out - I went to call Mr. Jennings.

GEORGE HAZLEWOOD WORRALL
. I am an officer. - I went to the house, and missed the things from the trunk in the lower room; I found this chisel just inside the door - we looked round, and found all the articles in this sack behind the door.

GEORGE GODFREY
. I heard of the robbery, and took the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I was an out-patient of St. Bartholomew-hospital; I went and got some pills there the day I was taken; I then went to Mrs. Elbury's and staid there from eleven o'clock in the morning till two in the afternoon; I then went to a public-house, and had a pint of half and half - Godfrey came in and said I was his prisoner - I went to Guildhall, and the woman first swore to
David Sullivan
; she then described me, and swore to me.
G. H. WORRALL. She said there was another person with him named Sullivan.
