JOHN STEVENS. I did not see any other person.

MARIA ELBURY
. I keep a green-grocer's shop at No. 15, Peter-street. I have known the prisoner about eight months - he lived in an up stairs room of mine about eight months ago; he has borne a good character. On the day he was taken up, he came to my house to ask me if the landlord had a room to let; I said Yes, and he said he would wait for the landlord; he waited from ten minutes past eleven o'clock till near two, and then went away, and I never saw him any more; I do not know what day of the week it was, but it was the beginning of May, about the 5th or 6th - I am quite sure it was the day he was taken up, because his father came the day after, to ask me if he had taken a room in the house - I am quite certain he did not move from the step of my door till two o'clock that day.
JURY to A. S. JENNINGS. Q. What time did you see him in the court where you live? A. From ten o'clock till past eleven; I keep a stand in the court.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1338.
JOHN FARRELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
William Taylor
, from his person .

WILLIAM TAYLOR. On Thursday last, about one o'clock in the day, I was near Holborn-hill
; I felt some one pulling at my pocket - I turned round, but did not observe anybody: a little boy told me that the prisoner had taken my handkerchief; he was then playing on the pavement with money; I challenged him with it - he denied it, and said if I would let go of his collar he would walk with me; I let him go; he ran from me - a gentleman stopped him.

JAMES HARVEY DAVIES
. I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief, and give it to another boy, who ran down Field-lane with it - it was a yellow handkerchief, and I think had some white spots on it; I do not think there was any red or blue in it - I did not tell Mr. Taylor sooner, because I thought they would beat me.
WILLIAM TAYLOR. My handkerchief was yellow, with white birds' eyes on it; I have not seen it since; this little boy seemed very much frightened.

JOHN LAWS
. I am a patrol. The prisoner was delivered to me.
Prisoner's Defence. I had been out of work, and wasgoing to Drury-lane to get some bottles; this gentleman said I had his handkerchief - I said I had not, and this boy said I took it.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Whipped and Discharged .

1339.
WILLIAM ALABASTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of April , 1 handkerchief, value 1d., the goods of a man unknown
, from his person .

GEORGE FREDERICK BOOTH
. I am inspector of St. Brides' watch; I was on duty on Ludgate-hill
about nine o'clock in the evening, on the 23d of April; I saw the prisoner go into a crowd; I watched him, and saw him take a handkerchief from a person unknown, and put it into his right hand pocket; I seized him, and just at that time there came a sudden rush in the crowd, which took the gentleman away - I took the prisoner to the watch-house; I am a chandler by trade, and have been an officer about twelve months - this is the handkerchief.
Prisoner's Defence. This man takes a false oath: I was going up Ludgate-hill, and saw the handkerchief on the ground - I took it up.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1340.
THOMAS ROBERTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of May , 13 pairs of unmade trousers, value 3l.6s., and 1 pair of spectacles, value 1s. , the goods of
John Pearson
.

JOHN PEARSON. I am a tailor , and live in Bell-alley
, near the Bank; I had thirteen pairs of trousers in my apartment - on the 8th of May at half-past five o'clock in the morning, I went out, and left the prisoner there; he went away, and returned at seven o'clock; he staid there with me until eight o'clock - I then went out, and returned in twenty minutes; the prisoner was gone, and the property likewise; I had left my spectacles on the bed - they were gone, as well as the trousers; I have never got the trousers since - the prisoner was taken on the Friday evening; I charged him with it - he said he knew nothing about it; he is a shoe-maker , and had been at work for my master the day before.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Was any other person there on the day of the robbery? A. No - a person worked there, but he was not there then; I do not know that he had not been there while I was out; I saw the trousers at five o'clock when I made my bed - the other man should have come to work at six; I had seen the prisoner working with spectacles the day before, but he did not borrow mine - I had had no quarrel with him; I was not drunk the day before - the prisoner and the other man were; I took up the other man.
COURT. Q. Who is the other man? A. A man named Joiner; I went to his lodging - the prisoner and he worked together; the prisoner did not return to me.

MARY ANN JAMES
. I live where Pearson does. On the morning of the 8th of May, at twenty minutes past eight o'clock, I was at my own door - the prisoner passed by me; he stumbled, and his hat fell off - he took it up and put it on; I saw it was full of something - he also seemed bulky round the waist.
Cross-examined. Q. Is it anything unusual for a tailor to take home work? A. His hat was full - he could hardly put it on.

HENRY AMBROSE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on Friday evening, and found these spectacles on him - he said he knew nothing of the prosecutor or the property, and was never at the place.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you find any more than one pair of spectacles on him? A. Yes, a pair which he said was his own; he afterwards acknowledged that these belonged to Mr. Pearson, though at first he said he did not know him, and his name was Wilkinson.(Spectacles produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. He allowed me to take the spectacles to work with - I put them into my pocket going out.
GUILTY . Aged 46.
Confined Six Months .

1341.
THOMAS JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of May , 18 yards of ribbon, value 27s., and 14 yards of other ribbon, value 18s. , the goods of
James Harris
.

CHARLES HENRY MARSHALL
. I am in the employ of James Harris, haberdasher , of Fore-street, City
. On the 28th of May, at half-past eight o'clock in the evening, the prisoner and a boy came into the shop together; I saw the boy draw his hand from a drawer of ribbons on the counter, and give something to the prisoner - I taxed them with it, and before I could get round the counter they ran off, and the prisoner dropped these ribbons against the door: they are my master's property; I followed, and never lost sight of him till the officer took him.

JAMES BUTLER RIDGWAY
. I saw the prisoner run out and drop something at the door; I ran on to London-wall, and the officer had got him - Marshall was on before me.

ABRAHAM HAM
. I am an officer. I stopped the prisoner - Marshall was pursuing him; these are the ribbons.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I went for three-quarters of a yard of shoe ribbon - the boy came in after me; the witness said, "Have you taken any ribbon" - he said, No; he ran out and dropped the ribbon at my feet.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1342.
WILLIAM ELLIOTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of May , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a man unknown
, from his person .

CHARLES GEORGE VINCENT
. I was a headborough of Clerkenwell. On Friday week I was crossing Fleet-market
, and saw the prisoner with another person; the prisoner took a handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket - they crossed the road; I took the prisoner by the collar, and was putting my hand round to his hand - he struck me as I was trying to get him into a pastry-cook's shop; I saw this handkerchief lying at his feet - I sent a boy after the gentleman, but he could not find him; I am in business at No. 23, Bowling-green-street; I have lived in the parish all my life - I do not know who the gentleman was.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you say, if I had not been soresolute you would not have taken me? A. No - I asked how he came to strike me, as he knew me long enough ago; I wished I could have got his partner.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1343.
RICHARD CRUTE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March , 60 printed bound books, value 20l.; 1 fender, value 5s.; 2 sets of fire-irons, value 5s., and 1 dial clock, value 20s., the goods of
William Capon Ayton
, his master .

No Evidence.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1344.
WILLIAM GRIMSHAW
&
SARAH KING
were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Edwin Mellett
, on the 16th of April , at Twickenham
, and stealing therein 3 spoons, value 1s.; 1 thimble, value 6d.; 1 gold pin, value 5s.; 20 lbs. weight of tea, value 7l.; 50 lbs. weight of bacon, value 30s., and 7 lbs. weight of raisins, value 3s., his property .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

EDWIN MELLETT. I live at Twickenham, and am a grocer . I was the last person up in my house on the 15th of April; it was fastened up securely when I went to bed - at seven o'clock the next morning I came down stairs, and found the door at the bottom of the stair-case bolted on the outside, so as to prevent my getting down; I then went down the other stair-case, and found the door at the bottom of that fastened with a gimblet; I pushed it open and went into the shop, and found the cannister lids lying about - I missed all these articles from the shop and the house; the value of the whole was 10l. or 11l; I went to Mr. Cockburn on the 17th - he produced to me three spoons with my initials filed out in a rough way; I saw the two prisoners in about a week in custody.

JAMES ROBINSON COCKBURN
. I am a silversmith, and live at Richmond. King brought these three spoons to me between eleven and twelve o'clock on the morning of the 27th of April, and a thimble, which Mr. Mellett did not claim; the marks on the spoons had been rubbed out; I mentioned that to her - she said she was not aware of any marks ever being on them; she had had them in her possession for twenty years; I said,"That is nonsense" - I did not suppose they had been rubbed out many hours; she said, "You need not be afraid, you know me;" I said, "I know you by sight, and that is all" - I at last gave her 5s. for them; I am confident the erasures could not have been made many hours; Mr. Mellett picked them out of the drawer.
Cross-examined by MR. CRESSWELL. Q. Then you had known her before? A. I had seen her, but did not know her name.

HENRY TODD
. I am a constable. I took King about a week after the robbery, at her own house at Hammersmith; Grimshaw lodged there, but he was not at home - he afterwards came and surrendered himself to me; when I took King, she said Grimshaw gave her the spoons; that he was going to work, and saw them laying in the road.
NOT GUILTY .

1345.
ADAM HALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 watch, value 3l.; 2 gold seals, value 1l.,; 1 gold key, value 7s.; 2 jackets, value 1l. 10s.; 4 shirts, value 12s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 waistcoat, value 4s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 8s., the goods of
John Lindsay
, in his dwelling-house .

JANE LINDSAY
. I am the wife of John Lindsay; he is at sea; our house is No. 24, Farmer-street, Shadwell
. On the 7th of April I went out at five o'clock in the afternoon, and left the prisoner, who was my lodger, in care of the premises; I left my property all secure in the back parlour - I returned after ten o'clock; I knocked at the door, but could get no admittance; I went to Mr. Jones, the publican, who got in backwards, and let me in; I then missed the property stated - it was worth more than 7l.; I have found a pair of trousers and a shirt at the pawnbroker's; the prisoner was taken on the Monday following.

Cross-examined by MR. J. ALLEY. Q. How long had your husband been gone? A. About six weeks; I had no other lodgers; he is a Greenwich pensioner - I knew I could find him at Mr. Smith's, an agent, in St. Maryaxe; I left a gallon and a half of rum and shrub in my room.

SOPHIA LARDEN
. The prisoner brought me this shirt and pair of trousers the beginning of April; I pawned them for him for 4s., and he gave me 4d.; I had not known him before.

Cross-examined. Q. In whose name did you pawn them? A. My own; I do not know the prosecutrix's servant - I saw her at Hicks's-hall, but did not ask her to point out the prisoner, for I knew him: he gave me a glass of gin.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in liquor, being left with a decanter three parts full of rum - I do not know what I did.
GUILTY. Aged 56.

Of stealing to the value of 99s. only . -
Transported for Seven Years .

1346.
HENRY GREENLEY
and
WILLIAM MEARS
were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Colquhoun
, Esq ,, on the 24th of April , at St. Clement Danes
, and stealing therein 1 hat, value 5s.; 1 pair of boots, value 15s., and 7 pairs of trowsers, value 20s., his property .

MR. JAMES COLQUHOUN. I am a student of law . On the 24th of April I left my chambers in Lincoln's-inn-fields
locked, about half past four o'clock - I returned at a quarter past seven o'clock; I found the doors of my sitting-room and bed-room open, and the books and clothes in confusion - I missed my hat from the table, a pair of boots, seven pairs of trowsers, and a great deal of other property; I found a hat, which was not mine, on the table, and the chisel, which I gave the officer - I do not know what parish my chambers are in.

JAMES BROWN
. I am a police officer. I took Greenley on the 16th or 17th of May; I found this hat on his head; it has Mr. Colquhoun's address in it - I went and gave him the information; I then went to Mears' lodging, and found these boots.
Cross examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. When was the robbery? A. On the 24th of April - I did not find them till the 16th or 17th of May.

GEORGE GRAVES
. I am an officer. I went to search Mears' lodging, and found these boots.

RALPH JOHN MASON
. I am a boot-maker. I made these boots for Mr. Colquhoun.
MEARS' Defence. My daughter brought these boots home on the 9th of May; I supposed they belonged to her.
Mears received a good character.

GREENLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 21. (See p. 612.)

MEARS -
GUILTY . Aged 52.

Of stealing only. - Mears
Transported for Seven Years .

1346.
JOHN WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May , 1 gelding, price 12l. , the property of
John Moyse
.

SIDNEY KERSEY
. I am servant to John Moyse: he lives in Little Coram-street - he is servant to Mr. Ellis, of Burton-crescent; I was employed to sell a gelding for Mr. Moyse, on the 16th of May; I got to Smithfield with it about four o'clock - several persons spoke to me about it; one man said, "Is the poney to sell?" I said Yes; he said,"Come out of the market, I have a gentleman here who wishes to see it;" I went with him to St. John's-street, where I saw the prisoner - I rode the poney up and down three times; the prisoner said, "That will do," and asked me the price; I said, "I must have fourteen guineas:" he said, "Will not 12l. do?" I said No; he then said he would give me 13l., and 10s. for myself; I said he should have it, and he asked me to take it to his house in Baltic-street, Old-street
: I went there, and saw him - he said, "Give one of the boys in the street the poney to hold; come in and I will pay you;" I left the poney with a boy, and went into the house; I saw the prisoner, and a person he called his sister - he told her to fetch a little ale; she said it was out; he said, "Fetch a pot of porter;" she did, and I drank of it; the prisoner then sent the man who first spoke to me in Smithfield to get a stamp - he did so; the prisoner said, "I am very particular in doing my business - I have it all on stamped paper;" his sister then went out, and took the poney from the boy - the other man went out to her, and said, "You must not take the poney away yet, the bridle does not belong to us;" he then came in, and gave me the bridle: the sister and the other man then went away- the prisoner said to me, "I have no money - I have paid it away for a load of corn." and he put this receipt for me to sign, but I would not; I read it, and thought it was a bill - the prisoner said, "It is a bill - you must take it"; he had told me he was a corn-dealer; when I would not take the bill he asked if I would take corn - I at last took the bill, believing it to be of value; I said I would carry it home, and see if master liked it, and if not I must bring it back again - if master had liked it I should not have interfered further; master sent me back - I went, and saw the prisoner; I said, "Master won't take this, it is not accepted, and not drawn on anybody;" he said he would not part with the poney that night, as he had to go into the country; but his sister has since brought it to the office.
NOT GUILTY .

1348.
THOMAS FLIGHT
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Isabella Scott
, widow , on the 21st of May , at St. Mary, Islington
, and stealing therein, 2 muslin dresses, value 15s., the goods of
Margaretta Scott
, spinster ; 3 books, value 10s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Davis
, spinster ; 1 hat, value 8s., and 1 pair of shoes, value 2s., the goods of
James Baron
; 1 box, value 2s., the goods of the said Isabella Scott; 1 hat, value 6s.; 1 pair of boots, value 4s., and 1 pair of gloves, value 1s. , the goods of
Edward Bond
.

ROBERT BROWN
. I am an officer of Islington. On the 21st of May, between three and four o'clock in the morning, I met the prisoner on the path which leads from Colebrook-row to the City-road, about three hundred yards from Mrs. Scott's; I asked what he had got - he made a very impudent answer; his pockets stuck out very much, and I took him to the watch-house - I found on him the articles stated in the indictment; the two gowns were wet - one was in his hat and one in his pocket.

PHOEBE SANDERS
. I live with Mrs. Scott, as servant. On Tuesday night, the 20th of May, I fastened up the house and went to bed between ten and eleven o'clock - everything was secure; I got up about half-past six and found the back kitchen window open, a piece cut out of the shutter, and the iron bars which go across, were forced - I know these two dresses - they were wet and were in the back kitchen.

ISABELLA SCOTT. I am a widow and rent this house. I went to bed between eleven and twelve o'clock; this small silver box is mine and was on the front parlour mantel-piece; I know these dresses and other articles - my house is in the parish of St. Mary, Islington; all these things were in the house the day before.
EDWARD BOND. I lodge at the prosecutrix's house. This is my hat; I left it in the hall, with these gloves in it - it was gone in the morning.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the property in the brick field, near the house.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 21.
